üìä Fundamental Analysis

fundamental-analysis financial-analysis

1.1 Why Focus on Fundamentals Instead of Just Technical Analysis

üìå Technical Analysis

  • Definition: Predicting future trends through charts of stock prices and trading volume.
  • Advantages: Intuitive, can see market sentiment, commonly used by short-term traders.
  • Disadvantages:
    1. Over-reliance on charts may ignore the real situation of the company.
    2. Short-term price movements are difficult to predict, easy to "chase rising and falling prices".
    3. Miss long-term opportunities: If you only look at charts, in 2000 you might think Amazon crashed, ignoring its later growth into a world giant.

üìå Fundamental Analysis

  • Definition: Study the company's operating conditions, financial health, and industry prospects to determine "whether the company is worth investing in".
  • Advantages:
    1. Sustainable in the long term, avoiding short-term speculation.
    2. Make investment "buying a business" instead of "buying a lottery ticket".
    3. Help discover undervalued good companies.
‚ö†Ô∏è Case:
  • 2000 Internet bubble: Many companies' stock prices soared, but had no profits, resulting in a crash.
  • Although Amazon lost money for many years, financial reports showed sustained high revenue growth, and fundamentals supported its long-term success.

üëâ Summary: Technical analysis is a "sentiment thermometer", fundamental analysis is the "health check report". Investment should focus on fundamentals, with technical analysis as a supplement.

1.2 How to Research a Company's Fundamentals

üîç Step 1: Search for Company Financial Reports on Google

  • Search keywords: Apple investor relations or Google annual report.
  • Official Investor Relations page ‚Üí Find Annual Report (10-K), Quarterly Report (10-Q).
  • Advantages: Most authoritative, directly from the company.
  • Disadvantages: Content is too long (hundreds of pages), difficult for beginners to quickly extract.

üîç Step 2: Use Google Finance

  1. Open Google
  2. Enter stock ticker:
    • Apple ‚Üí AAPL
    • Google ‚Üí GOOG
  3. You can see:
    • Summary ‚Üí Market cap, P/E ratio, dividend yield
    • Financials ‚Üí Income statement, balance sheet, cash flow
    • Statistics ‚Üí Valuation metrics (P/E, PEG, etc.)

üîç Step 3: Cross-verify with Financial News

  • Relevant news on Google News or Bloomberg, combined with financial data, to avoid "only looking at numbers without the story".

1.3 Case Study: Google and Apple

üçè Apple (AAPL)

  • 2023 Financial data (simplified):
    • Revenue: $383 billion
    • Gross margin: 43%
    • Net margin: 25%
    • Free cash flow: $100+ billion
  • Conclusion: High gross margin + stable cash flow + brand moat (ecosystem), a typical value investment target.

üîç Google (GOOG)

  • 2023 Financial data (simplified):
    • Revenue: $307 billion
    • Gross margin: 56%
    • Net margin: 22%
    • Main business: Advertising revenue (accounting for > 80%)
  • Conclusion: Advertising business growth is slowing, but cloud computing and AI are becoming new growth points.

üëâ Comparison:

  • Both are cash flow machines, but Apple is more stable, Google is more dependent on advertising.
  • Investment perspective: Apple is "defensive", Google is "growth + technology innovation".

1.4 Common Investor Mistakes

  • Only looking at stock price curves: Ignoring profit quality, easily deceived by short-term fluctuations.
  • Chasing news and hot spots: Forgetting to research company fundamentals.
  • Underestimating the importance of financial statements: In fact, gross margin and cash flow are the keys to whether a company can survive.

üéØ Activity

  1. Open Moomoo, search for TSLA (Tesla).
  2. Record three data points:
    • Gross margin
    • Net margin
    • P/E ratio
  3. Think: What do these data indicate? Why is Tesla's P/E ratio much higher than Apple's?
